sn15.8:1.1: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.
sn15.8:1.2: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn15.8:1.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and asked the Buddha,
sn15.8:1.4: “Worthy Gotama, how many eons have passed?”
sn15.8:1.7: how many eons have passed, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of eons.”
sn15.8:2.1: “But worthy Gotama, can you give a simile?”
sn15.8:2.3: “Consider the Ganges river from where it originates to where it meets the ocean. Between these places it’s not easy to calculate
sn15.8:2.4: how many grains of sand there are, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of grains of sand.
sn15.8:2.5: The eons that have passed are more than this.
sn15.8:2.7: how many eons have passed, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of eons.
sn15.8:2.9: This transmigration has no known beginning.
sn15.8:2.10: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.
sn15.8:2.11: For such a long time you have undergone suffering, agony, and disaster, swelling the cemeteries.
sn15.8:2.12: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
sn15.8:3.1: When he said this, the brahmin said to the Buddha,
sn15.8:3.3: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
